serious.translation[0].definitions[0].de: a serious situation, problem, accident etc is extremely bad or dangerous
serious.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Luckily, the damage was not serious.
Oil spills pose a serious threat to marine life.
The president was in serious trouble.
a serious accident on the freeway
serious.translation[0].definitions[1].de: important and needing a lot of thought or attention
serious.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: This is a very serious matter.
the serious business of earning a living
Be quiet, Jim. This is serious.
serious.translation[0].definitions[2].de: if someone is serious about something they say or plan to do, they really mean it and are not joking or pretending
serious.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: His voice suddenly became more serious.
Marry Frank?  You can’t be serious!
Is she serious about giving up her job?
serious.translation[0].definitions[3].de: someone who is serious is very quiet and sensible, and does not laugh and joke much
serious.translation[0].definitions[5].de: a serious romantic relationship is likely to continue for a long time
serious.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: It’s serious – they’ve been seeing each other for six months.
Are you really serious about her?
serious.translation[0].definitions[6].de: very interested in an activity or subject, and spending a lot of time doing it
serious.translation[0].definitions[6].ex: He’s become a serious golfer since he retired.
serious.translation[0].definitions[8].de: used to emphasize that you are talking about a large amount of something
serious.translation[0].definitions[8].ex: In industry, you can earn serious money.
serious.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: Vandalism is a serious problem in the area.
The driver was taken to hospital with serious injuries.
He is recovering from a serious accident.
The explosion sparked a fire which caused serious damage to their flat.
In the developed world, over-consumption is now a serious threat to health.
The economy was in serious trouble.
Neglecting to make a proper will can have serious consequences.
serious.translation[0].note_box[1].secti: very bad – used about problems, accidents, illnesses, or crimes
Violent crime is a serious problem in and around the capital.
The boy was taken to hospital with serious head injuries.
Fortunately, the damage to the car was not serious.
severe
very serious – used about problems, injuries, and illnesses
He suffered severe injuries in a car crash.
The problem became so severe that they had to bring water in from other countries.
severe epilepsy
grave
used about a situation that is very serious and worrying, especially because it is dangerous or seems likely to get worse
A thick fog descended and I knew that we were in grave danger.
The situation is grave – war now seems inevitable.
acute
used about an illness, problem, or situation that has become very serious or dangerous, and needs to be dealt with quickly
She was taken to the hospital suffering from acute appendicitis.
In San Diego, the shortage of skilled workers is acute.
desperate
used about a situation or problem that is very serious or dangerous, especially because a lot of people need urgent help
The situation is desperate – people here need aid before the harsh winter sets in.
The hospital is full of people in desperate need of medical attention.
critical
used about a situation that is very serious and dangerous and might get worse suddenly
In 1991, the food supply situation became critical.
Eight people were killed and four are still in a critical condition.
life-threatening
used about a situation, illness, or condition in which someone could die
Her child had a potentially life-threatening illness.
The situation was not life-threatening, but it was very worrying.
be a matter of life and death
to be extremely serious – used when a situation is very urgent or important
For people living with HIV, getting the right treatment is literally a matter of life and death.
not joking
not joking or laughing, or not pretending
His voice sounded serious.
They seem to be serious about their relationship.
solemn
very serious because of an important or sad occasion or ceremony
My father looked solemn, the way grown-ups look at funerals.
The judge read the verdict in a solemn voice.
grave
quiet and very serious – used especially about the way people look when something important or worrying happens
She consulted Doctor Staples and returned looking grave.
He listened with a grave expression on his face.
sombre
sad, quiet, or serious because something unpleasant or worrying has happened or is going to happen
They sat in sombre silence.
The meeting began in a sombre mood.
earnest
very serious and sincere – often used about someone who is young and not very experienced
He was a rather earnest-looking young man.
‘That’s wrong, ’ she said, her voice sounding very earnest.
